# Question

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

```julia
function audi_filter(df_cars)
    df_filtered = filter(row -> row["manufacturer"] == "audi", df_cars)
    
    model_conditions = ["a4", "a4 quattro"]
    df_audi_a4 = mapreduce(df_filtered, (left, right) -> merge!(left, [right; right]]), [])
    
    df_audi_a4[!, end] .= any.(map(row -> occursin.(model_conditions, split.(string, row[end]), r"\")) ? true : false, df_audi_a4[:, 1:end-1])))

    df_audi_a4[!, end-1] .= falses(size(df_audi_a4), 1)))
    
    df_audi_a4[!, end] .= map(row -> row[end-1]] == "true", df_audi_a4[:, 1:end-1]))

    return df_audi_a4
end
```

This function `audi_filter` takes a DataFrame `df_cars` as input and follows the provided instructions to filter, create a new column, and return the resulting DataFrame.
